ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The basics of political and social epistemology and epistemic accounts of democracy. The course provides an excellent overview of debates about truth in politics spanning a wide range of perspectives including normative political theory and perspectives from critical race theory. Landemore is excellent at taking texts familiar to political theorists and examining them afresh with new questions in mind.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course's biggest strength was Landemore's approach. She was always open to disagreement and her acknowledgement that these are not settled questions made the course especially instructive. The readings were enjoyable and manageable, and the intimate discussion made it yet more fruitful. The course had no real academic weaknesses. Looking back, it might have helped to spend more time on Epistemic Injustices than the syllabus permitted.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It was by far the best course I have taken at the Graduate School.
